Award.AwardTitle: The Evolution of Incentives and Social Structure under Imperfect Information
Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite the common conception of nature as "red in tooth and claw," almost all organisms, from soil bacteria to primates -including humans-, must cooperate with others to survive and reproduce. How such cooperation persists evolutionarily despite conflicts of interests is a central question in biology. The problem is exacerbated when individuals face uncertainty about factors affecting their payoffs, because this creates incentives for deception that would undermine cooperation. This project will study how incentives for cooperation and the related social structure evolve when individuals face uncertainty and have private information.

The PI and his colleagues will use a suite of mathematical tools originally developed in economics, called mechanism design theory. Mechanism design studies how appropriate incentive structures can be set up to prevent self-interested individuals from deceiving each other and undermining the desired outcome. However, classic applications of mechanism design theory, such as the design of auctions and trading schemes, usually presuppose an agent (such as a government) with the power of setting the "rules of the game". In contrast, natural selection acts on individuals that can alter the game only in limited ways by themselves. Hence, the evolved "rules of the game" represent the outcome of natural selection working in a decentralized way through individuals. The aim of this project is to understand how natural selection thus organizes interactions between individuals to achieve mutually beneficial outcomes.

The project's interdisciplinary approach will not only further our understanding of fundamental evolutionary processes, but also help in understanding how we in human societies can cooperate without relying on a central authority to tackle problems such as global climate change. It will also produce new results in social evolution theory that are sure to capture the public's attention, and will therefore aid in furthering science education and public understanding of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to study the evolution of social structure, incentives, and behaviors under imperfect information. In particular, we aimed at developing theory for how cooperation can persist in nature and human societies in the face of conflicts of interests and uncertainty, studying phenomena from the evolution and dynamics of social norms in human societies to interspecific cooperation between plants and microbes. Over the course of the project, which started September 2011 and ended August 2015, we have produced a total of 15 publications in top journals such as PNAS, The American Naturalist, and Evolution. We also have several more papers in advanced stages progress that will acknowledge the grant. Some of the main intellectual contributions of the project were:
1) Developing theory for the evolution of incentives under imperfect information, including the first ever biological application of the economic theory of mechanism design that deals with (Akcay 2012, J. Theo Bill; Akcay et al, 2012, PNAS)
2) Elucidating the interactions between different mechanisms for social evolution (Akcay and Van Cleve, 2014, Evolution)
3) Investigating the dynamics and robustness of cooperation in public goods and common pool resource dilemmas (Lade et al. 2013. Theoretical Ecology; Levin, 2014, PNAS)
4) Studying the emergence of global cooperation over climate change policies through small-scale aggrements (Hannam et al, 2015 Climatic Change; Pacheco et al. 2015 J. Math Biol)

Other work dealt with topics such as the comparative evolution of conflict in animal societies (Shen et al, 2014, Am Nat), the outcome of bilateral bargaining when players make prior investments that determine their valuation for the goods to be exchanged (Akcay et al, in review), the feasibility of informal mutual insurance in socio-ecological systems subject to climate variation. More recent work inspired by ideas from this grant in partly supported by it started to study the dynamics of social structure by means of social network dynamics (Ilany and Akcay, in review).

Overall, the work from this grant advanced our understanding of how social incentives, behaviors and social structure co-evolve in animal, human and coupled socio-ecological systems. In particular, we were aiming to inject some new perspective into social evolutionary theory, and believe that we have succeeded in that. As a truly interdisciplinary project that involved biologists and social scientists, we believe that our project also contributed to the ongoing integration of evolutionary theory with economics and other social sciences.

In terms of broader impacts, this project supported early career scientists, notably the senior personnel Erol Akcay, who has since obtained a faculty position. The results from this work has important implications for not only how animal and human sociality evolved, but also how human society deals with resource extraction and climate change issues. We have disseminated our results widely not just in journal publications but also in invited talks, plenaries and conference presentations.
